title: 'I can’t breathe': Fears Vietnamese woman is among 39 bodies after she sends mother desperate texts
text:
Fears Vietnamese woman is among 39 bodies after she sent mother dying texts

A Vietnamese woman who is feared to be among the 39 people found dead in the back of a refrigerated lorry texted her mother to tell her “I’m dying because I can’t breathe”, it emerged.

Pham Thi Tra My had paid £30,000 to be smuggled to Britain from her home in one of Vietnam’s poorest provinces but her family now believe that her three week journey ended in tragedy.

There are feared to be a number of Vietnamese nationals among the victims, sources close to the investigation confirmed to the Telegraph, despite police originally saying that they believed the migrants were Chinese.

The family of a second Vietnamese man Nguyen Dinh Luong, 20, said that they were concerned that he was also on the lorry after they had not heard from him since Tuesday.

One community group in the UK said that they had been contacted by at least ten families whilst an NGO based in Vietnam said seven sets of relatives had been in touch in an attempt to discover whether their loved ones were locked inside the refrigerated lorry. It is unclear if there is a crossover between the groups.

Police are now urgently working closely with the embassies of both Vietnam and China to try and establish the identities of those who had lost their lives.

A series of desperate texts, sent at the same time that the refrigerated trailer was making its way to Purfleet in Essex, where Pham Thi Tra My tells her mother "love you so much" and "I am sorry" More

Deputy Chief Constable Pippa Mills said that she “would like to speak directly to anyone who thinks their loved ones may have been in the trailer” as she assured them that the police only wanted “to give the victims’ families answers about what has happened”.

Anyone in Britain illegally who came forward with information will not face criminal action, she said.

DCC Mills revealed that Essex police now have four people in custody in relation to the deaths.

A 48 year-old man from Northern Ireland was arrested at Stansted Airport on Friday.

Earlier a 38-year-old man and a 38-year-old woman from Warrington Cheshire - named locally as Joanna and Thomas Maher – had been arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to traffic people and on suspicion of 39 counts of manslaughter.

The driver of the truck, named locally as 25-year-old Mo Robinson, from Northern Ireland, remains in custody after he was held on suspicion of murder in the early hours of Wednesday morning.

The news of the arrests came as the family of Miss Pham revealed a series of messages she sent at 10.30pm on Tuesday, as the container would have been making the crossing from Zeebrugge in Belgium to Purfleet in Essex, in which she told her mother that she “loved her so much”.

What we know so far

39 bodies found in lorry container They were 31 men, eight women Driver from Northern Ireland arrested Lorry cabin registered in Bulgaria in 2017 Container docked in Essex having travelled from Belgium Bodies discovered at Waterglade Industrial Park, Grays Two men and one woman arrested on suspicion of trafficking and manslaughter

In messages from the account saved as “daughter”, Miss Pham wrote: “I’m sorry Mum. My journey abroad hasn’t succeeded. Mum, I love you so much! I’m dying because I can’t breathe ... I’m from Nghèn, Can Lộc, Hà Tĩnh, Vietnam ... I am sorry, Mum.”

Just three hours later the container was opened on an industrial estate in Essex and the bodies of eight women and 31 men were found inside.

Miss Pham also included her address in one of the messages, which experts say is likely to have been done to show where to return her body to be buried.

Her family have now revealed that they had agreed to pay £30,000 to smuggle their daughter to Britain and she left their home in the poor Ha Tinh province in central Vietnam on October 3.

From there she travelled to China where she stayed for several days before flying to France.

Story continues
